ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a first introduction into thermodynamics, kinetics, and fluid flow I think I gained a lot of conceptual knowledge that will be useful in my future research even if it isn't directly related to it.

I learned the finer points of thermodynamics and was introduced to topics on kinetics and fluid flow. I learned how these topics are interrelated and how important they are to understanding metamorphic petrology as a whole.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Jay is a very clear lecturer and did an excellent job crafting the topics of lectures and teaching. Some of the homework questions near the end of the course seemed to be more busy-work and it would have been nice to have a bit more guidance on/expectations for the term paper.
The regular homework assignments of this course were interesting and provided an excellent personal assessment of my understanding of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. This course was a really applicable to geology and much more relevant than other general classes in thermodynamics would have been.
I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in processes that form and deform igneous and metamorphic rocks. These topics are vital to understanding the 'why' of metamorphism.
